4c:I[75400,["/_next/static/chunks/780ed9f12bd597e3.js","/_next/static/chunks/93fb432403aebbdd.js","/_next/static/chunks/6ed45c29e6db9297.js","/_next/static/chunks/ca6e69eece0158a1.js","/_next/static/chunks/c6ed05d45582b587.js","/_next/static/chunks/9674158a637507d8.js"],"AlertCircleIcon"]
2:T10b1,{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"FAQPage","mainEntity":[{"@type":"Question","name":"What's the best Argentine Malbec for the price?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"For under $5 USD, Alamos, Trumpeter, and Don Luigi are reliable daily drinkers. In the $8-15 range, Catena Malbec, Luigi Bosca De Sangre, Zuccardi Serie A, and Norton Reserva offer exceptional quality. For a splurge under $25, look for Catena Alta, Achaval-Ferrer Malbec, or Zuccardi Concreto. The sweet spot for price-to-quality is the $8-15 range -- you'll get wines that compete with $25-40 Malbecs exported to other countries."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"Can I ship wine from Argentina to my home country?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Yes, but it's complicated and not cheap. You can bring up to 2 liters per person in your checked luggage without extra duty in most countries. For larger shipments, specialty wine shipping services like Bodegas Argentina Export or DHL Wine handle the paperwork and logistics. Expect to pay $15-30 per bottle for international shipping. Some wineries offer direct international shipping, which can be more cost-effective for cases of 6+. Always check your destination country's import regulations."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"Is Argentine wine cheaper in Argentina?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Dramatically cheaper. A bottle of Catena Malbec that retails for $18-22 in the US costs $6-8 in Argentina. Premium wines that sell for $40-60 abroad are $15-25 locally. Budget wines that would cost $12-15 exported are $2-5 here. The savings are especially dramatic on mid-range and premium wines. This is one of the great perks of living in Argentina -- world-class wine at a fraction of global prices."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"When is harvest season (vendimia)?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Grape harvest in Argentina runs from late February through April, with the peak in March. The Fiesta de la Vendimia in Mendoza (usually the first week of March) is a massive celebration with parades, music, grape-stomping, and the crowning of the Vendimia Queen. It's Argentina's biggest regional festival. Visiting wineries during harvest is magical -- you'll see the crush in action, smell fermenting grapes, and taste juice straight from the press. Book accommodations months in advance."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"Do I need reservations for winery visits?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Yes, almost always. Unlike some wine regions where you can just walk in, Argentine wineries generally require advance reservations, even for basic tastings. During peak season (March-May and September-November), book at least 2-3 days ahead. For premium experiences at top wineries like Catena Zapata or Zuccardi, book 1-2 weeks in advance. Most wineries have online booking systems, or you can call directly. Some smaller bodegas are more flexible, but it's always better to call ahead."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"What's the difference between Lujan de Cuyo and Valle de Uco Malbec?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Lujan de Cuyo (800-1,100m altitude) is the traditional Malbec heartland. Wines tend to be richer, more full-bodied, with ripe dark fruit, chocolate, and plush tannins -- the classic Argentine Malbec profile. Valle de Uco (1,000-1,500m) is higher and cooler, producing Malbec with more acidity, freshness, and minerality -- think red fruit, florals, and a more elegant structure. Lujan is power; Uco is finesse. Many producers now blend both for balance. Both are excellent; it comes down to personal preference."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"Are there good Argentine wines under $5 USD?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Absolutely, and this is one of Argentina's greatest strengths. In the $2-5 range, look for Bonarda (Argentina's best-kept secret for everyday drinking), entry-level Malbecs from Alamos, Trumpeter, Fond de Cave, and Elementos, and Torrontes from Crios or Michel Torino. These wines won't win awards, but they're clean, well-made, and perfectly enjoyable for daily consumption. Many expats stock up on cases during supermarket 2x1 promotions and spend less than $50 a month on wine. Compare that to craft beer prices anywhere else."}}]}0:{"buildId":"XJ7f5RvYDcX4yjbAXmNYG","rsc":["$","$1","c",{"children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"flex flex-col min-h-screen","children":[["$","script",null,{"type":"application/ld+json","dangerouslySetInnerHTML":{"__html":"{\"@context\":\"https://schema.org\",\"@type\":\"BreadcrumbList\",\"itemListElement\":[{\"@type\":\"ListItem\",\"position\":1,\"name\":\"Home\",\"item\":\"https://expatsargentina.com\"},{\"@type\":\"ListItem\",\"position\":2,\"name\":\"Wine Guide\",\"item\":\"https://expatsargentina.com/wine\"}]}"}}],["$","script",null,{"type":"application/ld+json","dangerouslySetInnerHTML":{"__html":"$2"}}],"$L3","$L4","$L5","$L6","$L7","$L8","$L9","$La","$Lb","$Lc"]}],["$Ld"],"$Le"]}],"loading":null,"isPartial":false}

mb-4","children":"Mendoza is Argentina's undisputed wine capital. Sitting at the base of the Andes between 600 and 1,500 meters altitude, the region produces the Malbec that put Argentina on the global wine map. Lujan de Cuyo is the traditional Malbec heartland with bold, ripe fruit; Valle de Uco is the cooler, higher-altitude frontier producing more elegant, mineral-driven wines; and Maipu is the historic district with classic bodegas and easy access from the city."}],["$","div",null,{"className":"grid sm:grid-cols-2 gap-4","children":[["$","div",null,{"children":[["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm font-semibold mb-2","children":"Key Grapes"}],["$","div",null,{"className":"flex flex-wrap gap-1","children":[["$","span","Malbec",{"data-slot":"badge","data-variant":"outline","className":"inline-flex items-center justify-center rounded-full border px-2 py-0.5 font-medium w-fit whitespace-nowrap shrink-0 [&>svg]:size-3 gap-1 [&>svg]:pointer-events-none focus-visible:border-ring focus-visible:ring-ring/50 focus-visible:ring-[3px] aria-invalid:ring-destructive/20 dark:aria-invalid:ring-destructive/40 aria-invalid:border-destructive transition-[color,box-shadow] overflow-hidden border-border text-foreground [a&]:hover:bg-accent [a&]:hover:text-accent-foreground text-xs","children":"Malbec"}],"$L18","$L19","$L1a"]}]]}],"$L1b"]}]]}]]}],"$L1c","$L1d","$L1e","$L1f"]}]]}]}]}]
7:["$","section",null,{"className":"py-16 bg-muted/30","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"container mx-auto px-4","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"max-w-4xl know"}]]}]]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"space-y-6","children":[["$","div","0",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 items-center justify-center rounded-full border border-transparent px-2 py-0.5 font-medium w-fit whitespace-nowrap shrink-0 [&>svg]:size-3 gap-1 [&>svg]:pointer-events-none focus-visible:border-ring [a&]:hover:bg-destructive/90 focus-visible:ring-destructive/20 dark:focus-visible:ring-destructive/40 dark:bg-destructive/60 ml-auto text-xs","children":"Red"}]]}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm font-medium text-purple-600 dark:text-purple-400","children":"The Flagship"}]]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":[["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground mb-4","children":"Originally from Cahors in France, Malbec found its true home in Argentina. The high-altitude sun and dry climate produce deeply colored wines with plush dark fruit, velvety tannins, and a signature violet floral note. Entry-level Malbec is fruit-forward and easy-drinking. Premium bottlings from single vineyards can age for decades."}],["$","div",null,{"className":"grid sm:grid-cols-2 gap-4 mb-4","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"bg-green-50 dark:bg-green-950/20 p-3 rounded-lg","children":[["$","p",null,{"className":"text-xs font-semibold text-green-700 dark:text-green-300 mb-1","children":"Price Range"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm text-green-600 dark:text-green-400","children":"Budget: $2-5 | Mid: $8-15 | Premium: $20-50 | Icon: $80+"}]]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"bg-blue-50 dark:bg-blue-950/20 p-3 rounded-lg","children":[["$","p",null,{"className":"text-xs font-semibold text-blue-700 dark:text-blue-300 mb-1","children":"Best From"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm text-blue-600 dark:text-blue-400","children":"Mendoza (Lujan de Cuyo, Valle de Uco)"}]]}]]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"bg-amber-50 dark:bg-amber-950/20 p-3 rounded-lg mb-3","children":[["$","p",null,{"className":"text-xs font-semibold text-amber-700 dark:text-amber-300 mb-1","children":"Food Pairing"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm text-amber-600 dark:text-amber-400","children":"Asado (the classic), empanadas, provoleta, steak"}]]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"flex items-start gap-2 text-sm","children":[["$","$L20",null,{"size":"sm","className":"text-purple-500 flex-shrink-0 mt-0.5"}],["$","span",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":["$L21"," ","Look for 'Reserva' or 'Gran Reserva' for more complexity. A glass of Malbec with your milanesa at noon doesn't raise eyebrows. Wine is considered food here, not an indulgence. Most restaurants include a decent house wine option, and the waiter won't judge you for ordering a bottle at lunch. Don't overthink it -- when in Argentina, drink wine like Argentines do."}]]}]}],["$","div","1",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 pt-6","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"flex items-start gap-3 mb-3","children":[["$","$L30",null,{"size":"md","className":"text-purple-600 dark:text-purple-400 flex-shrink-0 mt-0.5"}],["$","h3",null,{"className":"font-semibold text-lg","children":"The Asado Wine Pairing Tradition"}]]}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Asado and Malbec is the national pairing, as sacred as steak and cabernet in the US. Bringing wine to an asado is expected -- one bottle per person is the minimum. The host provides the meat, guests bring the wine. Red wine with grilled beef is the default, but don't be afraid to bring a Torrontes for the provoleta and ensalada. Pro tip: bringing a premium bottle ($15+) signals respect for the asador's effort."}]]}]}],["$","div","2",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 pt-6","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"flex items-start gap-3 mb-3","children":[["$","$L12",null,{"size":"md","className":"text-purple-600 dark:text-purple-400 flex-shrink-0 mt-0.5"}],["$","h3",null,{"className":"font-semibold text-lg","children":"BYO Culture at Restaurants"}]]}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Many casual restaurants, especially parrillas and neighborhood spots, are relaxed about BYO wine. Some have a small 'descorche' (corkage) fee, typically $2-5 USD. Some don't charge at all. Always ask first, but this is a great way to enjoy better wine for less money when dining out. Higher-end restaurants usually don't allow BYO, but the markup on wine is still far more reasonable than in the US or Europe."}]]}]}],["$","div","3",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 pt-6","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"flex items-start gap-3 mb-3","children":["$L31","$L32"]}],"$L33"]}]}],"$L34"]}]]}]}]}]
b:["$","section",null,{"className":"py-16 md:py-24 bg-gray-50","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"max-w-3xl mx-auto px-4","children":[["$","h2",null,{"className":"text-3xl font-bold mb-8","children":"Frequently Asked Questions"}],["$","$L35",null,{"type":"single","collapsible":true,"className":"w-full","children":[["$","$L36","0",{"value":"faq-0","children":[["$","$L37",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"What's the best Argentine Malbec for the price?"}],["$","$L38",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"For under $5 USD, Alamos, Trumpeter, and Don Luigi are reliable daily drinkers. In the $8-15 range, Catena Malbec, Luigi Bosca De Sangre, Zuccardi Serie A, and Norton Reserva offer exceptional quality. For a splurge under $25, look for Catena Alta, Achaval-Ferrer Malbec, or Zuccardi Concreto. The sweet spot for price-to-quality is the $8-15 range -- you'll get wines that compete with $25-40 Malbecs exported to other countries."}]]}],["$","$L36","1",{"value":"faq-1","children":[["$","$L37",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"Can I ship wine from Argentina to my home country?"}],["$","$L38",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Yes, but it's complicated and not cheap. You can bring up to 2 liters per person in your checked luggage without extra duty in most countries. For larger shipments, specialty wine shipping services like Bodegas Argentina Export or DHL Wine handle the paperwork and logistics. Expect to pay $15-30 per bottle for international shipping. Some wineries offer direct international shipping, which can be more cost-effective for cases of 6+. Always check your destination country's import regulations."}]]}],["$","$L36","2",{"value":"faq-2","children":[["$","$L37",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"Is Argentine wine cheaper in Argentina?"}],["$","$L38",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Dramatically cheaper. A bottle of Catena Malbec that retails for $18-22 in the US costs $6-8 in Argentina. Premium wines that sell for $40-60 abroad are $15-25 locally. Budget wines that would cost $12-15 exported are $2-5 here. The savings are especially dramatic on mid-range and premium wines. This is one of the great perks of living in Argentina -- world-class wine at a fraction of global prices."}]]}],["$","$L36","3",{"value":"faq-3","children":[["$","$L37",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"When is harvest season (vendimia)?"}],["$","$L38",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Grape harvest in Argentina runs from late February through April, with the peak in March. The Fiesta de la Vendimia in Mendoza (usually the first week of March) is a massive celebration with parades, music, grape-stomping, and the crowning of the Vendimia Queen. It's Argentina's biggest regional festival. Visiting wineries during harvest is magical -- you'll see the crush in action, smell fermenting grapes, and taste juice straight from the press. Book accommodations months in advance."}]]}],["$","$L36","4",{"value":"faq-4","children":[["$","$L37",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"Do I need reservations for winery visits?"}],["$","$L38",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Yes, almost always. Unlike some wine regions where you can just walk in, Argentine wineries generally require advance reservations, even for basic tastings. During peak season (March-May and September-November), book at least 2-3 days ahead. For premium experiences at top wineries like Catena Zapata or Zuccardi, book 1-2 weeks in advance. Most wineries have online booking systems, or you can call directly. Some smaller bodegas are more flexible, but it's always better to call ahead."}]]}],"$L39","$L3a"]}]]}]}]

Cafayate is the main wine town, a gorgeous colonial village surrounded by red-rock canyons and vineyards. The region's signature is Torrontes, an explosively aromatic white grape that thrives nowhere else like it does here."}],["$","div",null,{"className":"grid sm:grid-cols-2 gap-4","children":[["$","div",null,{"children":[["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm font-semibold mb-2","children":"Key Grapes"}],["$","div",null,{"className":"flex flex-wrap gap-1","children":[["$","span","Torrontes",{"data-slot":"badge","data-variant":"outline","className":"inline-flex items-center justify-center rounded-full border px-2 py-0.5 font-medium w-fit whitespace-nowrap shrink-0 [&>svg]:size-3 gap-1 [&>svg]:pointer-events-none focus-visible:border-ring focus-visible:ring-ring/50 focus-visible:ring-[3px] aria-invalid:ring-destructive/20 dark:aria-invalid:ring-destructive/40 aria-invalid:border-destructive transition-[color,box-shadow] overflow-hidden border-border text-foreground [a&]:hover:bg-accent [a&]:hover:text-accent-foreground text-xs","children":"Torrontes"}],["$","span","Malbec",{"data-slot":"badge","data-variant":"outline","className":"inline-flex items-center justify-center rounded-full border px-2 py-0.5 font-medium w-fit whitespace-nowrap shrink-0 [&>svg]:size-3 gap-1 [&>svg]:pointer-events-none focus-visible:border-ring focus-visible:ring-ring/50 focus-visible:ring-[3px] aria-invalid:ring-destructive/20 dark:aria-invalid:ring-destructive/40 aria-invalid:border-destructive transition-[color,box-shadow] overflow-hidden border-border text-foreground [a&]:hover:bg-accent [a&]:hover:text-accent-foreground text-xs","children":"Malbec"}],"$L3f","$L40"]}]]}],"$L41"]}]]}]]}]

Pinot Noir is the star here -- lighter, more Burgundian in style -- and Malbec takes on a different character: more floral, with crunchy red fruit. The new generation of winemakers is producing restrained, elegant versions that have shed the grape's old reputation for being sweet and flabby."}],["$","div",null,{"className":"grid sm:grid-cols-2 gap-4 mb-4","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"bg-green-50 dark:bg-green-950/20 p-3 rounded-lg","children":[["$","p",null,{"className":"text-xs font-semibold text-green-700 dark:text-green-300 mb-1","children":"Price Range"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm text-green-600 dark:text-green-400","children":"Budget: $2-4 | Mid: $5-10 | Premium: $12-25"}]]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"bg-blue-50 dark:bg-blue-950/20 p-3 rounded-lg","children":[["$","p",null,{"className":"text-xs font-semibold text-blue-700 dark:text-blue-300 mb-1","children":"Best From"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm text-blue-600 dark:text-blue-400","children":"Salta (Cafayate), La Rioja"}]]}]]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"bg-amber-50 dark:bg-amber-950/20 p-3 rounded-lg mb-3","children":[["$","p",null,{"className":"text-xs font-semibold text-amber-700 dark:text-amber-300 mb-1","children":"Food Pairing"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm text-amber-600 dark:text-amber-400","children":"Ceviche, fresh salads, spicy empanadas, sushi, Thai food"}]]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"flex items-start gap-2 text-sm","children":[["$","$L20",null,{"size":"sm","className":"text-purple-500 flex-shrink-0 mt-0.5"}],["$","span",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Insider tip:"}]," ","Drink it young and cold. It produces juicy, medium-bodied reds with dark cherry fruit, soft tannins, and a friendly, approachable personality. This is the wine Argentines actually drink at home most nights -- it's cheaper than Malbec and endlessly drinkable."}],["$","div",null,{"className":"grid sm:grid-cols-2 gap-4 mb-4","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"bg-green-50 dark:bg-green-950/20 p-3 rounded-lg","children":[["$","p",null,{"className":"text-xs font-semibold text-green-700 dark:text-green-300 mb-1","children":"Price Range"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm text-green-600 dark:text-green-400","children":"Budget: $1.50-3 | Mid: $4-8 | Premium: $10-20"}]]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"bg-blue-50 dark:bg-blue-950/20 p-3 rounded-lg","children":[["$","p",null,{"className":"text-xs font-semibold text-blue-700 dark:text-blue-300 mb-1","children":"Best From"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm text-blue-600 dark:text-blue-400","children":"Mendoza (Maipu, San Rafael), San Juan"}]]}]]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"bg-amber-50 dark:bg-amber-950/20 p-3 rounded-lg mb-3","children":[["$","p",null,{"className":"text-xs font-semibold text-amber-700 dark:text-amber-300 mb-1","children":"Food Pairing"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm text-amber-600 dark:text-amber-400","children":"Pizza, pasta, casual asados, choripan"}]]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"flex items-start gap-2 text-sm","children":[["$","$L20",null,{"size":"sm","className":"text-purple-500 flex-shrink-0 mt-0.5"}],["$","span",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Insider tip:"}]," ","The best secret in Argentine wine. 2f:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"leading-normal font-semibold flex items-center gap-2","children":[["$","$L17",null,{"size":"sm","className":"text-blue-600 dark:text-blue-400"}],"Booking Tips & What to Expect"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","ul",null,{"className":"space-y-3","children":[["$","li","0",{"className":"flex items-start gap-2 text-sm text-muted-foreground","children":[["$","$L26",null,{"size":"sm","className":"text-blue-500 flex-shrink-0 mt-0.5"}],["$","span",null,{"children":"Book winery visits at least 2-3 days in advance, especially during high season (March-May, September-November)"}]]}],["$","li","1",{"className":"flex items-start gap-2 text-sm text-muted-foreground","children":[["$","$L26",null,{"size":"sm","className":"text-blue-500 flex-shrink-0 mt-0.5"}],["$","span",null,{"children":"Most wineries require reservations -- don't just show up"}]]}],["$","li","2",{"className":"flex items-start gap-2 text-sm text-muted-foreground","children":[["$","$L26",null,{"size":"sm","className":"text-blue-500 flex-shrink-0 mt-0.5"}],["$","span",null,{"children":"Morning tastings (10-11 AM) are best -- your palate is fresher and wineries are less crowded"}]]}],["$","li","3",{"className":"flex items-start gap-2 text-sm text-muted-foreground","children":[["$","$L26",null,{"size":"sm","className":"text-blue-500 flex-shrink-0 mt-0.5"}],["$","span",null,{"children":"Hire a driver or join a tour -- DO NOT drive between wineries. DUI laws are strict and police checkpoints are common"}]]}],["$","li","4",{"className":"flex items-start gap-2 text-sm text-muted-foreground","children":[["$","$L26",null,{"size":"sm","className":"text-blue-500 flex-shrink-0 mt-0.5"}],["$","span",null,{"children":"Many wineries offer lunch with wine pairings -- these are often the best dining experiences in the region"}]]}],["$","li","5",{"className":"flex items-start gap-2 text-sm text-muted-foreground","children":[["$","$L26",null,{"size":"sm","className":"text-blue-500 flex-shrink-0 mt-0.5"}],["$","span",null,{"children":"Expect to pay $10-30 USD per tasting at most wineries; some apply the fee to purchases"}]]}]]}]}]]}]
31:["$","$L20",null,{"size":"md","className":"text-purple-600 dark:text-purple-400 flex-shrink-0 mt-0.5"}]
32:["$","h3",null,{"className":"font-semibold text-lg","children":"Wine as Gifts (What to Bring to a Dinner Party)"}]
33:["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"When invited to an Argentine home for dinner, bring wine. Always. A mid-range Malbec ($8-15 USD) is the safe choice. If you want to impress, bring a premium bottle and tell the host about it -- Argentines love discussing wine. Avoid bringing the cheapest bottle from the supermarket; it's noticed. A Reserva or Gran Reserva from a recognized bodega (Catena, Zuccardi, Luigi Bosca, Norton) is always appreciated."}]
34:["$","div","4",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 pt-6","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"flex items-start gap-3 mb-3","children":[["$","$L4c",null,{"size":"md","className":"text-purple-600 dark:text-purple-400 flex-shrink-0 mt-0.5"}],["$","h3",null,{"className":"font-semibold text-lg","children":"The Fernet con Coca vs Wine Debate"}]]}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"While wine is the traditional drink of Argentine meals, fernet con coca-cola (a bitter herbal liqueur mixed with Coke) is the social drink of choice among younger Argentines. At parties and pregames, fernet flows freely -- wine is for the dinner table. Understanding this distinction will save you from showing up with a bottle of Malbec to a boliche (nightclub) pregame. Read the room: dinner party = wine, pregame/party = fernet or beer."}]]}]}]
39:["$","$L36","5",{"value":"faq-5","children":[["$","$L37",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"What's the difference between Lujan de Cuyo and Valle de Uco Malbec?"}],["$","$L38",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Lujan de Cuyo (800-1,100m altitude) is the traditional Malbec heartland. Wines tend to be richer, more full-bodied, with ripe dark fruit, chocolate, and plush tannins -- the classic Argentine Malbec profile. Valle de Uco (1,000-1,500m) is higher and cooler, producing Malbec with more acidity, freshness, and minerality -- think red fruit, florals, and a more elegant structure. Lujan is power; Uco is finesse. Many producers now blend both for balance. Both are excellent; it comes down to personal preference."}]]}]
3a:["$","$L36","6",{"value":"faq-6","children":[["$","$L37",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"Are there good Argentine wines under $5 USD?"}],["$","$L38",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Absolutely, and this is one of Argentina's greatest strengths. In the $2-5 range, look for Bonarda (Argentina's best-kept secret for everyday drinking), entry-level Malbecs from Alamos, Trumpeter, Fond de Cave, and Elementos, and Torrontes from Crios or Michel Torino. These wines won't win awards, but they're clean, well-made, and perfectly enjoyable for daily consumption. Many expats stock up on cases during supermarket 2x1 promotions and spend less than $50 a month on wine. Compare that to craft beer prices anywhere else."}]]}]
